PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 27 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of the alleged practice in states of the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics of blending their merino wool with Australian merino wool to then sell it as "Australian" merino wool.

(2) As the alleged practice would allow former Russian States to capitalise on Australian-funded "Woolmark" promotions what international trade conventions or rights of redress exist under which counteraction could be taken.
(3) What does the Government intend to do regarding the investigation of this alleged practice and to end this practice should it be proven true.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Raw wool from the Republics of Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan and the Baikal area of Russia is being sold into China, Turkey, Iran, India, Italy, the United States and Germany. There is strong evidence to suggest that some of this wool is being blended with Australian raw wool to make tops. This is normal commercial practice in the wool textile business.
The Government is not aware of any evidence to suggest that tops produced from these blends are being sold as 100 per cent Australian wool tops.

(2) If the honourable member has any concrete evidence to support this allegation, I will ensure that the matter is investigated further and that it is raised with the governments of the countries involved.
(3) As stated above, if specific proof of the practice were to be provided, the Government would raise the matter with the governments of the countries involved.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total cost of formulating the Government's Cultural Policy Statement currently scheduled to be announced on 18 October 1994.
(2) What was the breakdown of the total cost, including: (a) the name of each and every consultant engaged; (b) the amount paid to each consultant; and (c) any other, and what costs.
(3) What amount of time was spent by any and which officers within the Australian Cultural Development Office in the preparation of the Cultural Policy Statement.
(4) What organisations and individuals were consulted by or on behalf of the Government in relation to the preparation of the Cultural Policy Statement.
(5) What was the nature, extent and duration of each such consultation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(3) Over the period during which the Statement was developed, many officers of the Department of Communications and the Arts and its predecessor Departments contributed to the formulation of the Cultural Policy Statement. I am not prepared to direct the Department to expend the considerable resources necessary to obtain the detailed information requested. Details of consultants engaged by the Department of Communications and the Arts are set out in the Supplementary Information to the Annual Report 1993-94.

(4) Copies of the Green Paper `The Role of the Commonwealth in Australia's Cultural Development', released by the Government in 1992, were distributed and approximately 200 submissions were received in response.

An Advisory Panel was appointed in 1992. The members were: Prof Peter Spearritt, Mr Michael Leslie, Mr Rodney Hall, Ms Thea Astley, Ms Jill Kitson, Mr Bruce Petty, Mr Graeme Murphy, Ms Jenny Kee, Mr Leo Schofield and Ms Gillian Armstrong.
Ministers with responsibility for the Arts and the departments with responsibility for the Arts met with a large number of groups and individuals.

Public Forums to discuss the policy were held in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth. Several hundred people attended these discussions. Most forums were attended by the Minister for the Arts or other Ministers representing the Minister.

In addition to the large number of submissions, a great deal of other correspondence was received by the Ministers with responsibility for the arts and the Departments with responsibility for the Arts.
(5) Due to the large number of meetings and consultations, I am not prepared to direct the Department to expend the considerable resources necessary to obtain this information.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the National Guarantee Fund and the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 which contained provisions, subsequently withdrawn, which provided for the definition of securities under the Corporations Law to be added to by prescription:
(1) Under those provisions was it the intention to prescribe products of the Australian Stock Exchange which had the same high risk profile as futures contracts.

(2) What will the position be in relation to those products under the revised provisions of the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994 which the Attorney-General has released for public exposure and introduction in the Spring Session 1994.

(3) Was the effect of the withdrawn provisions that any default to the Australian Stock Exchange or the Options Clearing House or otherwise in such products or other prescribed products would be borne by the National Guarantee Fund which covers share trading.

(4) Will the effect of the proposed provisions be that any default to the Australian Stock Exchange or the Options Clearing House or otherwise in such products or other prescribed products will be borne by the National Guarantee Fund which covers share trading; if so, what steps did the Attorney-General take in relation to: (a) the withdrawn amendments; or (b) the proposed provisions, to ensure that defaults on such products will not prejudice the guarantee available to investors in the share market.

(5) Is the Attorney-General aware of any study as to whether the National Guarantee Fund will be sufficient to guarantee any loss to investors in: (a) share trading; (b) the options market; and (c) trading in the proposed high risk futures type products or other prescribed products: if so: (i) who conducted the study, and what were their qualifications, and (ii) what were the conclusions of the study.

(6) If a report as a result of such a study concluded that more capital was required to support the operations of the stock market, the options market and the proposed products: (a) how much additional capital was proposed; (b) how is the additional capital to be provided; and (c) when is the additional capital to be provided.

(7) If additional capital is not to be provided, what measures will be taken to ensure that investors in the share market, the options market or the proposed high risk futures type investments will be protected.

(8) What is the amount of: (a) the financial backing of the Sydney Futures Exchange Clearing House to guarantee the operation of the futures market; and (b) the Sydney Futures Exchange Fidelity Fund to compensate for fraud or defalcation of client monies or property in relation to futures trading.

(9) What is the equivalent amount which will be available to: (a) guarantee the high risk futures type products or other prescribed products to be traded on the Australian Stock Exchange; and (b) provide against fraud or defalcation in relation to monies or property lodged with dealers in relation to such products.

(10) Will the amount available to guarantee high risk futures type products or other prescribed products: (a) be separate from the amount available for fraud and defalcations; and (b) be separate from the amount available in relation to share market trading and/or options trading.

(11) If the amounts referred to in (10) are not separate, what consideration has been given to the effect on investors in the share market guarantee fund being exposed to such risks, and what was the result of that consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) It was, and remains, the intention to prescribe new financial products which will be subject to a regulatory framework which will protect investors using appropriate provisions of Chapter 7 and Chapter 8 of the Corporations Law. Each new product proposed under these provisions would be dealt with on a case by case basis according to its risk profile to ensure that the regulatory framework governing the product provided adequate investor protection. The provisions referred to will, facilitate the trading of new and innovative products on Australian securities and futures exchanges and, in particular, the trading of a new product (termed a `share ratio contract') by the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX).

(2) As above. The revised provisions of the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994, which had been released for public exposure on 5 September 1994, are largely the same as those that appear in the Corporations Law (Securities and Futures) Amendment Bill 1994, which has now been introduced in this session.

(3) The role of the National Guarantee Fund (NGF) is not to provide comprehensive cover in respect of any default of the type addressed by this question. In the context of share ratio contracts, I am advised that the relevant NGF provisions are contained in section 954N of the Corporations Law which allows a claim to be made on the NGF if a broker defaults in meeting a net payment obligation in the settlement system. The NGF is not, as suggested by the question, confined to the coverage of share trading. I am advised that claims against the NGF can be made in respect of other equity derivatives such as options traded on the ASX and its subsidiaries as well as in respect of property entrusted to broker who subsequently becomes insolvent, loss arising from either an unauthorised transfer of securities or from the failure to comply with the certificate cancellation procedures and a range of contract guarantees.

(4) and (5) Under the Corporations Law, claims against the NGF may be made in a range of circumstances. I am advised, however, that the coverage of the NGF is not so broad as to encompass `any default to the Australian Stock Exchange or the Options Clearing House'.

It is intended that the NGF will similarly cover claims in relation to the trading of share ratio contracts which could arise through the insolvency of a broker or through the failure of a member of the ASX to meet net payment obligations.
The Securities Exchange Guarantee Corporation (SEGC) is responsible for the operation of the NGF and the assessment of claims against it.

I am advised that the SEGC commissioned a firm of actuaries to conduct an independent actuarial analysis of the potential exposure of the NGF to trading in share ratio contracts. I am advised that the analysis was conducted by Tillinghast (previously Trowbridge Tillinghast) which is a subsidiary of Towers Perrin, one of the leading actuarial companies in the world. It is worth noting that Trowbridge Tillinghast undertook a review for the Sydney Futures Exchange to examine and make recommendations on the adequacy of the financial backing of the Sydney Futures Exchange Clearing House and the Sydney Futures Exchange Fidelity Fund.

The findings of the analysis of the NGF's exposure are that "the introduction of share ratio contracts would not lead to a serious undermining of the financial resources of the NGF". The report was based on information provided by the SEGC and it is assumed that share ratio contracts will only be written on major Australian companies. Tillinghast are of the opinion that under normal circumstances it is unlikely that the transaction of business in share ratio contracts would lead to claims on the NGF.

I am advised that studies in relation to the NGF have also been conducted at various times by the Board of the SEGC and that, in accordance with its statutory mandate, the Board regularly monitors the risk exposure of the NGF and reviews the minimum amount of the Fund.
Before prescribing any product under the proposed provisions, I would seek the advice of the ASC and the SEGC on issues such as the adequacy and coverage of the NGF.

(6) In light of the report by Tillinghast, which did not conclude that more capital was required to support the operations of the stock market, the options market and the proposed products, no response to this question is required.

(7) The basis of this question is that additional capital may be required, but the report by Tillinghast concluded otherwise. However, measures to protect investors in the share market and the equity derivative market are set out in the Corporations Law (primarily in Chapters 7 and 8), the Corporations Regulations and the Australian Stock Exchange Business and Listing Rules.
In relation to the trading of share ratio contracts those measures will include:
the application of the Chapter 8 provisions dealing with futures market manipulation, false trading and market rigging (ss 1259 and 1260)
the application of provisions dealing with false or misleading statements made to induce a person to enter into a contract for a share ratio
a prohibition on insider trading
licensing by the ASC of brokers and investment advisers in relation to share ratio contracts
obligation of brokers to maintain accounts in relation to dealing in share ratio contracts
a requirement for information to be provided to an individual about the financial ramifications involved in a share ratio contract.

Further specific rules to govern the trading of share ratio contracts will be set out in amendments to the Corporations Regulations and the ASX Business Rules. For example, the ASX proposes to use their existing derivatives clearing and that clearing house is supported by an efficient margining system known as the Theoretical Intermarket Margining System (TIMS) which provides for daily margining of positions in the market.
As stated in (5), the Board of the SEGC regularly monitors the risk exposure of the NGF and reviews the minimum amount of the Fund.
(8) I am advised that:
(a) the financial backing of the Sydney Futures Exchange Clearing House to guarantee the operations of the futures market is $100 million; and
(b) that the SFE Fidelity Fund according to the last reported accounts stands at $11.7 million.

(9) As set out in (4) and (5) the NGF provides a mechanism to protect the interests of investors in share ratio contracts. I am advised that the NGF stood at $126.3 million with current liabilities of $425,000 as at 30 June 1994. Where the amount of the Fund is less than the `minimum amount' (currently determined to be $50 million) the SEGC may determine that a levy is payable on certain transactions or by the Australian Stock Exchange.

I am advised that under the relevant contract guarantee provisions of the NGF (Part 7.10 of the Corporations Law) there would be no limit on the payment of successful claims under Division 6B of Part 7.10 in relation to share ratio contracts and the total amount of the Fund is available to meet any claims.

I am advised that the NGF will also compensate, in particular circumstances, investors who suffer loss of money or property held by an ASX member as a result of the Member becoming insolvent (Division 8 of Part 7.10). I am advised that there is a limit in respect of the total amount that will be paid out of the NGF in respect of any one member's insolvency. I am advised that the current limit is $7 million. In addition to the coverage afforded by the NGF the ASX Options Clearing House would ordinarily have available funds which include margin and deposit funds.

I am advised that brokers are required under ASX Business Rules to maintain professional indemnity cover for claims arising from fraud or defalcation in relation to monies or property lodged with brokers. I also note that ASX Business Rule 1.1 which is monitored by the ASX requires that brokers always have sufficient liquid capital to meet their obligations.

(10) I am advised that the NGF provisions of the Corporations Law do not provide for the separation of funds available in relation to fraud and defalcations or in respect of share market and options trading activities. It is not proposed that the NGF have separate funds available for separate products. I am advised by the ASC that segregation of funds should not be necessary, if the total amount of the NGF advised by Tillinghast is adequate, or greater than required, to cover the reasonably foreseeable exposures in relation to share contracts and securities .

(11) I am advised by the ASC that, given the size of the NGF and the arrangements for risk management practices by the ASX and the Options Clearing House, including the assessment and calling for margins, investors should not be unduly exposed to risks in relation to investment products which cannot be met from the NGF.
The findings of the report by Tillinghast are also relevant to this issue. See answers to (4) and(5).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to licensing arrangements and the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 which contained provisions, subsequently withdrawn, which provided for the definition of securities under the Corporations Law to be added to by prescription:
(1) Under those provisions was it the intention to prescribe products of the Australian Stock Exchange which had the same high risk profile as futures contracts.
(2) What will be the position under the draft provisions of the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994 which the Attorney-General has indicated will be introduced.

(3) Will products prescribed under the original provisions, subsequently withdrawn, and/or the revised provisions be able to be offered to investors by licensed securities dealers who do not have futures brokers licences.

(4) Will all such licensed dealers be required to satisfy the Australian Securities Commission that they have the expertise to trade high risk derivative products equivalent to that required by licensed futures brokers.

(5) Will such licensed dealers include licensed dealers who are not members of the Australian Stock Exchange: if so, will such licensed dealers be required to be members of a self-regulatory organisation as required for licensed futures brokers.
(6) If such licensed securities dealers will be required to be members of a self-regulatory organisation, what self-regulatory organisation or organisations will satisfy that requirement.

(7) In relation to the Australian Stock Exchange and each such self-regulatory organisation: (a) what procedures will it have in place to ensure that persons advising investors in such products have the necessary expertise to do so; (b) will such a body have in place a system for the registration and examination of persons advising or soliciting orders on behalf of licensed brokers equivalent to that maintained by the Sydney Futures Exchange; and (c) what procedures will exist for ensuring that licensed brokers dealing in the proposed high risk futures type products have: (i) adequate financial backing to ensure that investors do not suffer as the result of the trading in such products by such brokers either on their own behalf or on behalf of other clients, and (ii) adequate procedures in place for the margining, reporting and settlement of such products.

(8) Will the procedures and systems referred to in (7) apply to all members of the Australian Stock Exchange or such self-regulatory organisation entitled to offer such products to clients, or only to some of those members entitled to offer such products; if some only, which ones.

(9) If all or any such licensed security dealers are not required to be members of a self-regulatory organisation or will not be required to comply with the procedures and systems referred to in (7), how will it be ensured that each of the procedures and systems mentioned in (7) will be addressed, and is the Attorney-General aware that in relation to futures trading it is quite common for advice to be given, or orders to be taken, by brokers who are not dealing members of a relevant market.

(10) Will the Australian Stock Exchange or another self-regulatory organisation be sufficiently trained and experienced to deal effectively with issues of compliance and surveillance so as to identify and prevent fraud and other market abuses in relation to the trading of high risk futures products on the Australian Stock Exchange; if so, what is the size of the staff directly responsible for this function, and what experience has that staff, or its individual members, in detecting abuses in relation to futures contracts; if not, why not.

(11)(a) Will there be a compliance and surveillance regime specifically created so as to cope with the trading of futures contracts on the Australian Stock Exchange; (b) will the current compliance and surveillance regime which operates with respect to derivatives' other than futures on the Australian Stock Exchange be used in this role; and (c) is this a satisfactory result which is in the interests of the investing public; if so, how.

(12) With reference to the background paper on the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994, it is indicated that the licensing provisions under Chapter 7 of the Corporations Law relating to securities are more onerous than those of Chapter 8 concerning futures; for each of the points listed below, is the Attorney-General aware: (a) that the pre-requisite for obtaining a futures brokers license is that the holder of a futures brokers licence must be a member of a self-regulatory futures organisation; (b) that the requirement for membership of a self-regulatory futures organisation was intended, and has operated in practice as, a key element in maintaining the integrity of the futures industry in Australia; (c) of the fraudulent and abusive practices which existed in relation to futures trading prior to the introduction in the 1986 Futures Industry Code and which resulted in substantial losses to individual unsophisticated investors; (d) that, as a consequence of the requirement for membership of a self-regulatory organisation, extensive and specialised compliance and financial requirements established by the Sydney Futures Exchange apply to futures brokers; (e) no such requirement exist for holders of securities dealers licenses; (f) a securities dealers licence will only be required where a dealer is in the business of dealing in securities whilst a futures brokers licence is required for even isolated dealings on behalf of other persons; (g) that investment advisers under Chapter 7 of the Corporations Law may pass client orders so long as they are `disinterested' from the actual trades for example, they do not receive commission on trades; and (h) that futures advisers may not pass on orders and can only provide advice.
(13) Having regard to the matters raised in (12), why does the explanatory paper to the draft bill state that the licensing requirements under Chapter 7 are more onerous than under Chapter 8.

(14) Having regard to paragraph (12) (g) and (h), will the requirement applicable to futures advisers referred to in those paragraphs apply to investment advisers who will be able to offer the proposed Australian Stock Exchange products to clients; if not, why not.

(15) With reference to section 1126 of the Corporations Law, which sets out criteria for approval of futures exchanges, has the Attorney-General satisfied himself that the Australian Stock Exchange has arrangements which satisfy these provisions, in particular, has the Australian Stock Exchange made or will it make, satisfactory provision for each of the arrangements indicated below: (a) `for the equitable and expeditious settlement of claims and grievances between members, being claims and grievances relating to transaction of business by members in their capacity as members'; and `for appropriate mechanisms for the conciliation and settlement of disputes between members and their clients, being disputes concerning dealings in futures contracts by members on behalf of their clients or concerning transactions between members and their clients in connection with such dealings'; (b) `for the qualifications for membership, including the necessary standards of training and experience for: (A) responsible officers of bodies corporate that; and (B) natural persons who; are, or propose to be members'; (c) `for the manner in which members are to conduct their business of dealing in futures contracts so as to ensure efficiency, honesty and fair practice in relation to such dealing'; and (d) for the admission as members of persons licensed or proposing to be licensed under the Corporations Law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) See answer to Question No 1739 at (1).
(2) See answer to Question No 1739 at (2).

(3) It is intended that the Corporations Regulations will provide that dealings in, or the provision of advice on, share ratio contracts will be restricted to members of the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX), who are also members of the Options Clearing House (OCH), and other persons whose dealers licence expressly allows dealings in, or the giving of advice on, share ratio contracts. It is proposed that the ASX Business Rules applying to share ratio products will restrict ASX members to dealing or advising clients through employees who had met requirements in the Business Rules and had satisfied the Board of the ASX as to their knowledge and experience in trading and advising on share ratio contracts. Those Business Rules are examined by the ASC and they are also subject to review and possible disallowance by the Attorney-General.

In relation to persons who are not members of the ASX and who wish to trade share ratio contracts I am advised that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) would impose conditions on the licence of such persons requiring a standard of education and knowledge similar to that required by the ASX.

(5) It is possible, though unlikely, that a licensed dealer trading share ratio products would not be a member of the ASX so long as the ASC has approved that person for trading in share ratio products. In deciding whether a person should be allowed to deal in share ratio contracts I would expect that the ASC would take into account whether that person is a member of a self-regulatory organisation such as the ASX.
(6) Licensed dealers will not necessarily be required to be a member of a self regulatory organisation. Also see (3) and (5) above.

(7)(a) In relation to representatives of ASX, members dealing in, or advising on, share ratio contracts will be required to satisfy the standards set by the ASX in consultation with the ASC as to their level of expertise, probity, financial backing and trading procedures and be approved as an `Approved Ratio Adviser'. These requirements will be set out in the ASX Business Rules. The Business Rules will be examined by the ASC and will also be subject to review and possible disallowance by the Attorney-General.

(b) I am advised the ASX proposes that Approved Ratio Advisers must attend an ASX conducted training program, study a range of literature produced by ASX, sign a formal undertaking and be subject to supervision by a senior representative of the broker with experience to the satisfaction of ASC in equity derivatives.

The program contemplated by ASX differs from Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) procedures in that SFE Registered Representatives must pass a formal examination and attend a longer training course. However, I am advised that the requirements are similar to those prescribed by the SFE for holders of a proper authority granted by the holder of a securities dealers licence seeking authority to advise in individual stock futures traded on the SFE.

(c)(i) The Business Rules of ASX impose stringent capital adequacy requirements which take into account all transactions on the account of a broker including activities in the share market and equity derivatives markets. For ASX capital adequacy purposes the only assets allowable are current assets capable of realisation within 30 days. Non current assets are excluded.

(ii) ASX Members have been trading deliverable and cash settled equity derivatives since 1976. I am advised that the margining, reporting and settlement procedures already in place are appropriate to share ratio contracts. ASX through OCH, the subsidiary through which equity derivatives are cleared, recently introduced a new risk management system—TIMS, an acronym for Theoretical Inter Market Margining System. TIMS is a system for margining derivative contracts which was developed by the Options Clearing Corporation (OCC) of Chicago. TIMS is acknowledged as an advanced and appropriate system for the risk management of equity derivatives.

(8) The procedures and systems outlined in question (7) will apply to all members of the ASX proposing to trade share ratio contracts. Non-members of the ASX will be required to satisfy the ASC in relation to similar requirements before they can trade share ratio contracts.

(9) I am advised that persons who are not members of the ASX or persons whose dealers licences do not expressly allow dealings in, or the giving of advice on, share ratio contracts will not be allowed to so deal or advise. Before such a person would be approved by the ASC to trade share ratio contracts they will be required to meet similar requirements to those referred to in (7).

In relation to OCH, all such orders must be put through the market, so that a clearing member of OCH takes responsibility for that order. Section 851 of the Corporations Law also requires that a securities adviser have a reasonable basis for a securities recommendation.

(10) I am advised by the ASC that it considers that the introduction of trading of share ratios does not appear to raise any new or specific problems for the ASC or ASX's existing surveillance and enforcement program. Staff of the ASX have extensive experience of leveraged financial derivatives with risk profiles similar to futures contracts and have conducted and regulated derivatives markets in Australia since 1976. I am advised that the ASX have surveillance systems in place to maintain the integrity and stability of the markets for which it is responsible and that the ASX Surveillance Division liaises closely with the OCH on activity in the physical and derivatives markets. I also understand that the ASX has conducted a review of surveillance procedures to ensure that the type of market abuses and potential risks involved in equity derivatives and futures trading are understood.

The ASX Membership Division have for many years dealt with compliance issues for two equity derivative markets—the Australian Options Market and the Australian Financial Futures Market (which traded equity based futures contracts and was active from 1985 to 1990).

I am advised that there are currently 12 compliance officers in the ASX Membership Division. In addition there are 6 State managers all of whom have experience in monitoring compliance by Members with the Business Rules.

The ASX share ratio market will be traded on SEATS (Stock Exchange Automated Trading System) rather than by open outcry. This means that there is a complete audit trail of electronic trading in share ratio contracts.

I am advised that the ASX surveillance is based on the SOMA (Surveillance of Market Activity) computer program. SOMA receives a live "real-time" feed of SEATS activity which is then interrogated by the program to produce "alerts" based on pre-set price and volume parameters. These alerts are then addressed in real-time by market analysts specialising in surveillance matters. Where warranted an investigation is commenced.

I am advised that in the prevention area, the ASX conducts an extensive program of presentations to brokers and market participants to demonstrate its surveillance capabilities and to promote responsible market behaviour. The program is designed to:
dissuade illegal market activity
reinforce market participants' awareness of their responsibilities
raise market participants' awareness of ASX Surveillance capabilities and
encourage communication between the market and its regulator.

I am advised that the ASX Surveillance Division has a staff of 9 involved in investigation and analysis and 5 computer staff. Three investigative staff have extensive knowledge of financial derivatives, including futures, and the potential market abuses arising from trading.

(11)(a) & (b) I am advised that the trading of share ratios is integrally linked with the existing equity market provided by the ASX and will be conducted on the same screen trading system and the existing compliance and surveillance regime will be used for trading in share ratio contracts.
The ASX's current compliance and surveillance regime which operates with respect to derivatives will be used in this role.
With respect to surveillance and investigation of market abuses, I am advised that:
the SEATS system provides an audit trail of every event on the market; and
independently, OCH maintains full client details of each clearing member for all derivative trading, facilitating regulatory scrutiny of unusual activity when warranted.

ANSWER.PARA: See (10) for details of the surveillance system.

PARA.TAB: (c) I am advised by the ASC that the regulatory package for the trading of share ratios contract is appropriate to protect the investing public.

(12)(a) and (b) I am aware that there are detailed licensing regimes in Chapter 7 and Chapter 8 of the Corporations Law. The detailed requirements of the licensing regimes in Chapter 7 and Chapter 8 differ and judgments may be made about their respective merits. However both licensing regimes are capable of providing an appropriate regulatory framework for the trading of derivative products such as share ratio and options contracts. The ASC imposes as a prerequisite for obtaining a stock brokers licence that the applicant must be a member of a self-regulatory stock exchange organisation.

The provisions of the draft Corporations Law (Securities and Futures) Amendment Bill 1994 only permit the prescription of products which are relevant agreements entered into on the markets of futures exchanges or securities exchanges. The Corporations Regulations will prescribe a particular type of instrument. The effect of the prescription will be that an instrument can only be traded on a securities market of a securities exchange if it is to be dealt with under the regulatory regime set up by the legislation, the regulations and the proposed business rules.

The necessary effect of that restriction is that only members of securities exchanges may enter into share ratio agreements on the securities exchanges. Securities exchanges, in particular Australian Stock Exchange Limited, have extensive and specialised compliance and financial requirements which are imposed upon members of the exchange as a consequence of membership. Those rules are designed to ensure the financial stability and integrity of the market operated by ASX, and of members themselves. Accordingly, in the context of the proposed share ratios market, securities dealers who engage in trading in the market will be subject to similar extensive and specialised compliance and financial requirements to those established by Sydney Futures Exchange in relation to futures brokers. Indeed, in the view of the ASC, the requirements imposed by means of the proposed ASX Business Rules will be appropriate for the trading in share ratio contracts.
12(c) and (d) I am aware of these matters which were the reason for the introduction of the Futures Industry Code.
12(e) and (f) Yes I am aware. Requirements similar to those for futures brokers exist for holders of stock brokers licences and these requirements are enforced by both the ASC and the ASX.

It is correct to state that a futures broker's licence is required, by any person who deals in a futures contract on another persons behalf (sll42(a) Corporations Law), whereas a securities dealer's licence is required where a person carries on a securities business (s780(a) Corporations Law). As noted in the explanatory memorandum for the Futures Industry Bill 1986, the futures licensing system is similar to that which was operating under the Securities Industry Act. The inclusion of a specific requirement on futures brokers to be licensed, as a condition of dealing on behalf of another person, is the major difference. As is made clear by the explanatory memorandum (paragraphs 149, 150, 276—279), and also by the explanatory paper on the second exposure draft of the Futures Industry Bill 1985 (paragraphs 175-179, 324-328), the main purpose of the difference was to prohibit the practice of `bucketing' where orders of a client are not placed for execution on the relevant futures market. Rather, the broker either takes the other side of the transaction or matches it with equal and opposite orders from other clients. The effect of this is that clients do not obtain the benefits of clearing house arrangements.

I am advised that this concern does not arise in the proposed market for share ratio contracts, since the regulatory regime to be set up by the draft provisions can only apply in relation to contracts entered into on a stock market of a securities exchange. This ensures that parties to those contracts have the benefit of the Clearing House arrangements set up for the Australian Options Market, and also the benefit of National Guarantee Fund protection.

In addition, the requirement for securities licensing where a person carries on a securities business, is in fact more extensive than the requirement to be licensed only when acting on behalf of other persons. "Securities business" is broadly defined (in s93) as a business of dealing in securities. In turn, "dealing" is defined to include a wide range of activity in relation to securities, including attempting or inducing a person to make or to offer to make an agreement in relation to the acquisition, disposal, subscription for or underwriting of securities.

Accordingly, securities licensing is required for a wide range of persons who, in the futures context, would not require futures brokers' licences because they do not act on behalf of any other person.

(g) and (h) An investment adviser's licence empowers a person to carry on a business of advising other persons about securities, or publishing securities reports (s77 Corporations Law). As soon as the activities of the investment adviser fall within the very broad definition of `dealing'—that is, buying, selling, attempting or inducing other persons to make agreements about buying, selling and so on then a securities dealer's licence is required.

A regulation will be made preventing the giving of advice for dealing in share ratios unless the adviser or dealer has satisfied the ASC as to its expertise and education in relation to share ratios. In addition, only ASX members will be allowed to execute orders for share ratios and ASX members will be required to have a client agreement form signed by the client and an approved ratio assigned to the client before orders may be executed.
(13) The responses to the matters raised in (12) make it clear that:

in the context of the proposed share ratios market, the combined effect of securities dealers' licensing arrangements and the specialised compliance and financial requirements established by the ASX for those able to deal in share ratio contracts have the effect that the operation of the compliance system for the proposed share ratio market is no less onerous than futures brokers licensing arrangements.

to the extent that securities dealers licensing is required wherever a securities business is carried on, regardless of whether dealing is conducted on behalf of others or not, the licence requirements under Chapter 7 can be considered more onerous than under Chapter 8, because of their wider application.

(14) It is proposed that investment advisers may only pass on client orders in relation to share ratio contracts where they have a securities dealers licence and their licence has been endorsed by the ASC to advise on or deal in share ratios. I am advised that in this regard there are protections to ensure that proper advice is given to investors in relation to share ratio contracts.

(15) The provisions referred to will not be applicable to the trading of share ratio contracts. However, there are similar provisions in the Corporations Law which apply to the ASX which will be taken into account before final approval of the regulatory requirements for the trading of share ratio contracts is given.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to clearing arrangements and the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 which contained provisions, subsequently withdrawn, which provided for the definition of securities under the Corporations Law to be added to by prescription:
(1) Under those provisions, was it the intention to prescribe products of the Australian Stock Exchange which had the same high risk profile as futures contracts.
(2) What will the position be under the revised provisions of the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994 which the Attorney-General has indicated will be introduced.

(3) What steps has the Australian Stock Exchange taken to establish appropriate clearing arrangements for any such products including for the items listed below: (a) appropriate legal arrangements for the clearing of such products including: (i) clear and unambiguous clearing rules which provide for such products. (ii) clear and unambiguous application of an appropriate clearing house guarantee, and (iii) clear and unambiguous legal relationships between the Australian stock Exchange members trading such products, between such members and clearing house, between such members and investors, and between investors and the clearing house; (b) appropriate computer systems: (i) for the recording and allocation of trades, (ii) for the margining and settlement of products on a daily basis and intra-day basis, and (iii) to enable the clearing house to be at all times aware of and to manage its risks in such high risk products; and (c) appropriate staff with expertise in the clearing of futures type products.
(4) Have such arrangements as yet been approved by the Australian Securities Commission and/or the Attorney-General.

(5) Have such arrangements as indicated in (3) been approved, or will such arrangements be required to be given consideration, on the same basis as an applicant for a clearing house under Chapter 8 of the Corporations Law, which requires the Attorney-General to approve a clearing house `if, and only if, he is satisfied that: (b) the body's business rules as relate to the registration of futures contracts made on a futures market of the futures exchange; (c) the body's business rules making satisfactory provision for the expulsion, suspension or business rules make satisfactory provision for the expulsion, suspension or disciplining of members for a contravention of the business rules or for contravention of this Chapter; and (d) the interest of the public will be served by granting the application'; if not, why not.
(6) Has the Attorney-General had regard to the provision made under the proposed arrangements for the guaranteeing of contracts effected under the arrangements; if not, why not.
(7) If the proposed arrangements will not be considered on the above basis, on what basis will the proposed arrangements be considered by the Attorney-General.

(8) Will the consideration of the proposed clearing house arrangements be any less onerous than those applicable to previous applications for approval of clearing houses under Chapter 8 of the Corporations Law.

(9) Will the Attorney-General ensure that any such arrangements have features to protect the integrity of trading in futures type products such as: (a) financial backing and guarantees specially allocated to such trading; (b) restricting the exposure of clearing members in relation to the size of their net worth; (c) requiring clearing members to contribute securities over and above their normal margining arrangements to a minimum of $1 million which will be available in the event of any default by the clearing member so as to reduce the risk of exposure by other participants in the market and their clients; and (d) otherwise requiring clearing members holding position in such products to contribute financial backing to the clearing house.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) See answer to Question No 1739 at (1).
(2) See answer to Question No 1739 at (2).

(3)(a) I am advised that share ratio contracts will be traded on the Australian Stock Exchange's (ASX's) market through its Securities Exchange Automated Trading System (SEATS) and cleared and settled through the ASX's Options Clearing House (OCH).

I am advised that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) is working with the ASX to ensure that the provisions of the Business Rules relating to the clearing of share ratio contracts by the OCH are appropriate.

I am advised that the ASX has adopted the Chicago Mercantile Exchange developed risk management margining system known as TIMS (Theoretical Intermarket Margining System) which allows both end of day and intra day margining of ASX's clearing house members and, through them, their clients. I am advised that the greater speed of calculation of risk and prudent margins of TIMS significantly lowers the risk of individual market participant failure to which a derivatives market is exposed and therefore the systemic risk to the market. The share ratio Business Rules will create a special category of SEATS operators who will be authorised by their clearing member employers to trade in share ratio contracts on SEATS. The operators will be required to undergo special training and will be specially accredited.

(b) I am advised that clearing members will be required to register share ratio contracts with OCH after trade. By virtue of an electronic interface between SEATS and OCH, registration will occur electronically immediately after the bid and offer are matched on the SEATS screen. I am advised that the share ratio Business Rules will provide that on registration of the share ratio contract, the buying and selling side to the contract will be split apart by novation, the original contract being replaced by two contracts. By the first contract the seller sells to OCH and by the second contract the buyer buys from OCH. This is the typical arrangement in options and futures markets and indeed with the advent of the T + 5 settlement regime, in the ASX equities market.

I am advised that under the Business Rules the buyer and seller on registration will be subject to the disciplines of OCH' s margining system. It is mandatory to pay risk margins in respect of open contractual positions. TIMS calculates a risk margin that is the most likely overnight adverse movement in the value of the Share Ratio contract and is the amount the liquidating value of a Share Ratio contract would change in a worst case scenario overnight. This margining process will be repeated daily for the risk margins in addition to the `mark to market' process dealt with below. With TIMS in place, if there is significant `intra-day market movement', margin calls for payment may be made during the course of that day.

Once the contract is registered the buying and selling clearing members open `bought' and `sold' positions will be marked to market daily. The clearing members' positions in Share Ratios will be assessed daily in accordance with movements in the market. An assessment of profits or losses on those positions will be made in line with that market movement and will be posted to the relevant account of the clearing member as with option contracts. As a result of this process OCH calculates the daily amount owing on each account (separate and in addition to risk margins) and the clearing member will be required to pay the amount owing to OCH.

(c) I am advised that experienced risk management staff of the ASX monitor the market and use TIMS. The daily margining processes are a common feature of risk management procedures for derivatives, futures contracts or otherwise. I am also advised that the ASX has undertaken these clearing settlement and margining processes for many years in the conduct of its other derivatives markets and has sufficient software and systems to accommodate share ratios.

(4) The Business Rules which will govern the clearing and settlement of share ratio contracts have been approved in principle by the ASC. Upon lodgement, these Business Rules will be the subject of an approval process by the ASC and will also be subject to review and possible disallowance by the Attorney-General.

(5) The matters relevant to the approval of a clearing house for a futures exchange are among the factors that will be taken into account in any consideration of the appropriateness of the clearing arrangements for share ratio contracts.

(6) & (7) I am advised it is intended that the National Guarantee Fund (NGF) will stand behind the OCH for the proposed products by virtue of Part 7.10 Division 6B of the Corporations Law. Default by a clearing member in meeting net payment obligations which include obligations with respect to share ratio contracts will be covered by the NGF by virtue of section 954N of the Corporations Law and the associated Business Rules.

(8) The approval of arrangements for the clearing of share ratio contracts by OCH differ from and are not readily comparable to the approval of a clearing house under Chapter 8 of the Corporations Law. I am advised that the clearing arrangements for the proposed products currently being examined by the ASC will be appropriate for the trading of those products. In determining what will be appropriate, consideration will be given to the provisions which apply to the clearing of similar products by other clearing houses.

(9) I am advised by the ASC that the clearing arrangements for share ratio contracts will provide adequately for the supervision and maintenance of fair, orderly and efficient markets and the protection of investors. The questions set out arrangements which apply to one particular market. Different but equally effective arrangements may be adopted which will provide adequately for the supervision and maintenance of fair, orderly and efficient markets and the protection of investors.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to investors and to the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 which contained provisions, subsequently withdrawn, which provided for the definition of securities under the Corporations Law to be added to by prescription:
(1) Under those provisions was it the intention to prescribe products of the Australian Stock Exchange which had the same high risk profile as futures contracts.

(2) What will the position be under the revised provisions in the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994 which the Attorney-General has released for public exposure and introduction in the Spring session.

(3) Has the Attorney-General considered whether such characterisation of such high risk products as securities will mislead investors as to the true nature of such products; if so, what means will be adopted to ensure that investors are not so misled.

(4) Has the Attorney-General considered how the characterisation of such high risk products or other prescribed products as securities will affect; (a) the provisions of trust deeds detailing restriction on investment of funds solicited from investors; (b) fund management arrangements; (c) investment restrictions of Government entities; (d) investment restrictions of semi-government corporations; (e) provision in the memorandum and articles of corporations restricting investment; (f) provisions of superannuation arrangements restricting investment in high risk products; and (g) the provisions of Regulation 8.3.02 of the Corporations Law restricting investment in futures by fund managers who do not hold futures brokers licences; if so, what was the result of that consideration.

(5) How will the Attorney-General ensure that the characterisation of such products as securities will not: (a) mislead the entities referred to in (4) into trading in products or excessively trading in products so as to breach their restrictions on investments; and (b) enable persons employed by such entities to avoid the restrictions of management or those of the entities constitution designed to restrict, or to control, the trading in high risk products.

(6) Will the Attorney-General ensure that investors will not suffer loss as a result of such high risk products being characterised as securities having regard to the matters raised above; if so, how.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) See answer to Question No 1739 at (1).
(2) See answer to Question No 1739 at (2).

(3) In the development of the proposed regulatory arrangements for the trading of share ratio contracts investor protection has been a primary consideration. I am advised that a comprehensive risk disclosure/client agreement form and explanatory booklet will be required to be provided to prospective investors in the proposed products and will ensure that investors are aware of the true nature of the product.

I am advised that share ratio contracts are a form of investment where the instrument itself has the features traditionally linked with a futures contract but the adviser/dealer expertise and investment applications are more closely aligned with the securities market. Given that they are cash settled equity derivatives, it is not considered that the categorisation of share ratios as securities will mislead investors. Cash settled equity derivatives are already traded on the securities market operated by the ASX, the Australian Options Market, and cleared by OCH.

The Corporations Law (Securities and Futures) Amendment Bill will not directly affect the definition of securities, so the issue of its effect on private instruments and the arrangements and restrictions mentioned should not arise.

(g) I am advised that the characterisation of share ratio contracts as securities is appropriate in the context of fund managers who are securities dealers, but do not hold futures brokers licences, bearing in mind the risk and volatility characteristics of share ratios and their close association with the underlying securities. Indeed, I am advised that institutional investors consider that the proposed share ratios product will be a useful vehicle for fund managers, as they will be able to protect themselves against general market risk.

(5)(a) As stated in (4), this type of issue should no longer arise. However, as noted at (3), I am advised that a comprehensive risk disclosure/client agreement form and explanatory booklet will be required to be provided to prospective investors in share ratio contracts and will ensure that investors are aware of the true nature of the product.
(b) This is a matter for the internal management of entities referred to in (4), who are responsible for fulfilling their legal requirements.

(6) I am advised by the Australian Securities Commission that the overall regulatory package for the trading of share ratio contracts will provide an appropriate regulatory regime for trading of share ratio contracts. The legal characterisation of a product as a security or futures contract has no direct bearing on the risk of loss through trading of either product. I will appropriately take the advice of my Department and the ASC on the proper regime for the trading of products in the derivative area.
Any trading in products on securities or futures markets results in gains and losses. This is the nature of such trading.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 which contained provisions, subsequently withdrawn, which provided for the definition of securities under the Corporations Law to be added to by prescription:
(1) Under those provisions, was it the intention to prescribe products of the Australian Stock Exchange which had the same high risk profile as futures contracts.
(2) What will the position be under the revised provisions of the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994 which the Attorney-General has indicated will be introduced.

(3) With reference to the explanatory memorandum to the Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994, which states at paragraph 1 that: `The Bill will facilitate the trading of new and innovative products on Australian securities and futures exchange'. What products will be facilitated by the bill for trading on a futures exchange.

(4) Will the bill be capable of enabling consideration of the trading by futures exchanges of new and innovative products including those products considered as either: (a) equities; (b) bonds; (c) debentures; or (d) prescribed interests; if not, why not.
(5) Will the proposed amendments potentially allow any futures contract to be prescribed as a security.

(6) With reference to the explanatory memorandum, it is stated that the need for the amendments is because of the development of hybrid products, is the Attorney-General aware: (a) that the Commodities Futures Trading Commission of the United States have set down criteria for determining whether a product is of the nature of a hybrid; (b) that the proposed Australian Stock Exchange Share Ratio product to be prescribed under the proposed amendments will not satisfy those tests; (c) of on what basis it is contended that the proposed share ratio product is a hybrid product rather than a futures contract as such; (d) that the definition of a Share Ratio contract under the proposed regulations, to be made under the agreement is substantially similar to the definition of `adjustment agreement' within the definition of futures contract under Chapter 8 of the Corporations Law; (e) of on what basis it is stated in the explanatory paper to the draft Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1994 that the existing provisions of Chapter 8 of the Corporations Law are not appropriate for the

QUESTION.PARA: trading of proposed Australian Stock Exchange Share Ratio products; and (f) that the explanatory paper to the draft bill refers to the fact that the Australian Securities Commission has recommended that there should be similar regulatory treatment of products with similar functional characteristics, and on what basis then is the view taken that products which have the functional characteristics of futures contracts should not be regulated under the provisions of the Corporations Law relating to futures contracts.

PARA.TAB: (7) With reference to the explanatory memorandum to the draft bill, which states that the Australian Stock Exchange cannot trade the proposed Share Ratio product because of the definitions of securities and futures contract, will the proposed product fall within the current definition of futures contract; if so, why cannot such a product be traded on the Australian Financial Futures Market Pty Limited, which is an approved futures market and a subsidiary of the Australian Stock Exchange.

(8) With reference to the explanatory memorandum which states that it is anticipated that pending the completion of the current law reform review process by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee that it is anticipated that only Share Ratio contracts will be prescribed under proposed amendments, and if this is so, why are the amendments so wide in their effect.

(9) With reference to the exposure draft background paper which was released for comment on 6 September 1994, which states that `the prescription of agreements under the new paragraphs of the definitions will be reserved for special occasions when it can be demonstrated that the ordinary operation of the Corporations Law is not appropriate', is it not a fact that the ordinary operation of the Corporations Law is appropriate for the regulation of futures contract; if not, why not.
(10) How can it be demonstrated that the ordinary operation of the Corporations Law is not appropriate.

(11) With reference to the background paper, which states that `because of the close relationship between a share ratio contract and securities which are already traded on the ASC, the Government is of the view that, in this particular case, it is reasonable for share ratio contracts to be traded on a securities exchange notwithstanding that a share ratio contract is not within the existing definition of securities and has features of a futures contract' is the close relationship mentioned above closer than the relationship between any other futures contract and its underlying basis, and is it not true that the share ratio contract has more than mere `features of a futures contract' and is by definition under the Corporations Law a futures contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) See answer to Question No 1739 at (1).
(2) See answer to Question No 1739 at (2).

(3) The legislation has been designed to facilitate the trading of new products developed by the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) and the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) on securities and futures exchanges.

The proposed amendments are designed to provide an interim flexible regime for the development of innovative financial products by ensuring that a tailored and appropriate regulatory regime applies for each new product. Of necessity, therefore, the proposed arrangements are designed to deal with products the existence of which has not yet been anticipated in a flexible way by use of regulations and business rules where appropriate. Bearing in mind the current examination of derivatives by the Corporations and Securities Advisory Committee, the Attorney-General has indicated that it is not expected that any products other than the proposed share ratios product are likely to be brought forward under the new provisions at this time. However, any futures or securities exchange which can demonstrate a new product requiring the application of the legislation will be able to make submissions to the Attorney General seeking prescription under the legislation. In that event, there will be appropriate exposure and comment upon the proposals, as there has been for share ratio contracts.

(4) There has been no detailed proposal put forward for the trading of any new product by any futures exchange which would require Government consideration beyond the amendments contained in the Bill or provisions already contained in the Corporations Law.

The Bill will be capable of enabling consideration of the trading by futures exchanges of new products, to the extent that those products require application of the legislation. However, in relation to each new product, the Attorney-General and the ASC will need to be satisfied as to the appropriateness and desirability of trading the new product on the particular exchange and as to the existence of appropriate enforcement, compliance and surveillance mechanisms to ensure necessary investor protection.
(5) No. The legislation is restricted to the trading of `relevant agreements' as are defined in the Corporations Law.

While they introduce more flexibility into the trading of new products on an exchange it will be necessary for an exchange seeking the benefits of the legislation to demonstrate that the features of the relevant product are appropriate for the relevant prescription and that satisfactory investor protection is in place.

It is Government policy to assist the Australian securities and futures industries to grow and develop. These industries are significant to Australia's future as a mature and stable economy and through these industries Australia can develop as an important financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region. The existing Australian exchanges hold key positions in these industries.

The Government recognises that the future success of the exchanges depends in part on their capacity to develop innovative new products. Both the ASX and the Sydney Futures Exchange have shown that they have the capacity to do this and that they wish to go further. It is important that this activity is not inhibited by uncertainty as to the classification of derivative products under the Corporations Law and regulatory structures which may encourage business to go elsewhere.

In light of this the Government has decided to amend the Corporations Law to introduce more flexibility into the definitions of `securities' and `futures contracts'. The Government accepts that the present definitions can operate to prevent the trading of a new product on a particular exchange, even though there may be valid reasons why it should be able to trade on that exchange.

The criteria of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) of the United States is one factor that has been taken into account in the development of the Government's proposals in relation to the trading of new derivative products. However, it is noted that the CFTC and the Securities Exchange Commission have agreed previously to prohibit futures contracts over individual shares. I understand that that decision was based on the difficulty of accommodating those instruments under that current futures or securities legislation, whereas, in Australia individual share futures are permitted and are currently traded on the SFE. The Government believes that a more flexible approach to regulation of financial products is in the best interests of all participants in the finance industry.

(f) In its Report on OTC Derivatives Markets the ASC recommended that law reform in the equity derivatives area should have as its first objective `to ensure similar regulatory treatment of products with similar function or characteristics'. The Report also made suggestions regarding the criteria which should guide the proposed regulation-making power and emphasised that the power should be used in relation to products that have the function or characteristics of products caught by the existing definitions. In the ASC's view, policy should be driven by functional rather than legal analysis.

Regulation of share ratio contracts via the Corporations Law, prescribed regulations and ASX Business Rules will meet this criteria. It fulfils the very objective set out by the ASC in its Report and the ASC agrees with the Government's flexible approach in this area.

(7) A share ratio contract does not fall within the existing definition of securities. However, there is a close relationship between a share ratio contract and securities which are already traded on the ASX. Share ratio contracts require a knowledge of the performance of individual shares. I am advised that stockbrokers are equipped to provide advice about the performance of shares and with the proposed special requirements for licensing of trading in share ratios will be equipped to advise on such contracts. The Government is, acting on the advice of the ASC, of the view, therefore, that in this particular case it is reasonable for share ratio contracts to be traded on a securities exchange.

(8) Financial markets and the needs of their users are evolving in ways that were not envisaged during the 1980s. New and innovative products continue to be developed and traded by derivatives markets. In putting forward these reforms the Government is simply responding to a request by an exchange to facilitate the trading of a particular product. The Australian Securities Commission supports the introduction of some flexibility into the legislative regime applying to the securities and futures to deal with emergency issues in changing market circumstances. Similar requests may be made in the future, although none have been proposed to date. Provided adequate safeguards are in place to ensure the protection of investors and the integrity of markets Governments must be able to respond to such requests and the needs of the users of financial markets. The Bill provides a mechanism for responding to such requests.

The flexibility will enable, where appropriate, the trading of new products on a particular exchange in circumstances where there are valid reasons why such products should be so traded but are obstructed by the existing definitions of `securities' and `futures contracts'.

(9) and (10) See (7). It has been recognised that the existing provisions of the Corporations Law could restrict derivative product development initiatives and may operate to inhibit the development of innovative new products. Share ratio contracts are but one example of this. It is for this reason and in recognition of the existing difficulties with the definitions of `securities' and of `futures contracts' that the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee is undertaking a review of the regulation of derivatives. The proposed legislation will attempt to provide some flexibility pending that review.

It is not suggested that there are any features of Chapter 8 which are necessarily inappropriate for regulation of the trading of share ratios. Rather, should the SFE choose to develop and trade a risk management product similar to share ratio contracts which is clearly a futures contract or Chapter 8 agreement, then the SFE could do so because the provisions of Chapter 8 are not inappropriate. There may be other appropriate regimes for trading such products and the proposed package for trading share ratios on the ASX is an example of this.
(11) Each financial product must be considered on its own merits. The proposals of the Bill in relation to the particular product are not necessarily applicable to other futures contracts.

It should be noted that the background paper merely states that there is a close relationship between share ratio contracts and the underlying securities. There probably is a closer relationship between share ratio contracts and ASX's markets than many other commodities and their derivative markets because the underlying components of the derivative markets are created and traded on ASX's markets and by the ASX members who would trade share ratio contracts.
