TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 19 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of concerns that a proposed Queensland Government transfer of State Forests in the Wet Tropics Area into national parks could compromise the rights of native title holders in the area.
(2) What steps are being taken to ensure that adequate negotiations are carried out with indigenous people in the Area to ensure that their rights are maintained.

(3) Given that management of the Wet Tropics is a joint Federal and State Government responsibility, what assistance can the Federal Government provide to ensure that the transfer of lands to national parks does not pre-empt native title determinations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of the proposed transfer.

(2) The transfer of lands from State Forest to National Parks is a State Government responsibility. It is also a matter for the State Government to ensure that adequate negotiations are carried out with Aboriginal people regarding this matter. While the Commonwealth's role in this is necessarily limited, I have taken a number of steps to ensure that Aboriginal concerns are taken into account in the management of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area.

The Commonwealth Government enacted the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Act 1994 which requires the Commonwealth Government to nominate an Aboriginal person for membership of the Wet Tropics Management Authority Board and also ensures that the Commonwealth Environment Minister uses his/her best endeavours to ensure that any advisory committee established by the Authority Board includes Aboriginal representatives.
On the Commonwealth's nomination Mr Noel Pearson, Executive Director of the Cape York Land Council, was appointed as a member of the Wet Tropics Management Authority Board on 23 September 1994.

The matter of the transfer of lands from State Forest to National Park and the rights of indigenous peoples will be discussed at the next Wet Tropics Management Authority Board meeting. However, I should point out that the proposed transfer of lands is not an Authority initiative per se.

(3) This matter will be discussed at the next Wet Tropics Ministerial Council and I can assure the Honourable Senator that I will ensure that there is proper consideration of possible native title rights relating to the proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the material disclosed in the NRMA prospectus regarding the effects of de-mutualisation on social security and other Government payments:
(1) Did the department write to the NRMA on 14 September 1994 stating that `the NRMA free share issue cannot be exempted from the normal application of the social security income and assets tests'.
(2) Was that information provided by NRMA directors to members by way of supplementary prospectus or press release.
(3) Did the department also advise the NRMA on 14 September 1994 that the receipt of cash from the renunciation of free shares would not be considered as income.

(4) Does section 8 of the Social Security Act, in conjunction with section 1072A(2)(a), bring into account for the purposes of the income test an `income amount' consisting of `profits (whether of a capital nature or not)'.

(5) Was the department aware that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) advised the Treasurer (Mr Willis) that cash from renunciation of the NRMA `free shares' would be fully subject to capital gains tax as being profits of a capital nature unless the tax law was amended.

(6) How is the advice given by the department on the cash received from the renunciation of rights to shares consistent with the Social Security Act or with the advice given to the Treasurer by the ATO.

(7) If cash received from renunciation of rights to shares is exempt from the income test, can companies assist pensioners to avoid the income test by offering renounceable rights to fully paid shares in lieu of dividends.

(8) Will the Minister table representations which were made to the Minister and the department by the NRMA on the treatment of the NRMA `free share' and cash alternatives together with file notes and advisings held or provided by the department in relation to NRMA representations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, the Department did write to the NRMA advising that social security clients holding NRMA shares, which they received at no cost, would be treated in the same manner as other social security clients who owned shares.

(2) The Minister is not aware whether the NRMA issued a supplementary prospectus or press release following the Department's advice. However, advice on the treatment of NRMA shares was provided by social security staff in Sydney to an NRMA hotline run by the Council of the Ageing (COTA).
(3) The Department did advise the NRMA on 14 September 1994 that the actual receipt of free NRMA shares, or their cash equivalent, would not be considered income for social security purposes.

(4) Yes, however, the free share entitlement, or the cash equivalent, is not considered to be `profit' as the members have not invested any capital in order to obtain the value received. Therefore, sections 8 and 1072A(2)(a) are not relevant to the NRMA share float.
(5) Yes, the Department was aware of the advice provided to the Treasurer by the Australian Taxation Office.

(6) The policies of the Department of Social Security are determined by the Social Security Act and therefore consideration of taxation legislation is not relevant to the treatment of NRMA shares under the Social Security Act.

(7) No. Once dividends are declared a person has a legal right to receive those dividends. If they elect to use those dividends to obtain renounceable rights to other shares, the dividends are still assessed as income. This policy is consistent with the present treatment of dividend reinvestment plans where shares are issued in lieu of dividends.

(8) The NRMA organised with my Office to provide me with a briefing on the NRMA share issue on 3 May 1994. The NRMA subsequently wrote to the then acting Assistant Secretary of the Department's Retirement Programs Branch requesting preferential treatment for the share issue and provided me with a copy. The NRMA wrote to me again on 17 August 1994 referring to a letter of 7 July. Neither my office nor the Department has any record of the letter of 7 July 1994 referred to by the NRMA. The Department responded to the NRMA's submission on 14 September 1994. Copies of this correspondence have been supplied to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 8 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australia Remembers: 1945-1995 activity, why does the application for seeding grant form require the endorsement of a local federal member of parliament and exclude endorsement by a senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senators' question:

PARA.TAB: One of the most important elements of the Australia Remembers program is supporting and encouraging community activities. The mechanism I have set up to do this centres on the involvement of each Federal Member of the House of Representatives and the application form for seeding funding reflects this.

Dealing with the 147 members who represent approximately 70 000 constituents in each electorate maximises the opportunity for all Australians, wherever they live across the nation, to be involved in Australia Remembers 1945-1995.
On this basis, I have asked each member to establish local Australia Remembers committees to plan, organise and fund events and activities put forward by people within the electorate.
Commonwealth seeding funding will be available where applications meet the funding criteria, are recommended for funding by the committee and endorsed by the federal member.

I have asked federal members to endorse applications to help me prioritise applications and keep the number of requests to manageable levels. One of their roles is to ensure that bids do not amount to more than the $20 000 limit available to each electorate.

I wrote to all senators about these arrangements on 21 October requesting their support for this important and special program. Any senator who is aware of a deserving project in his or her state should make sure the appropriate federal member or the Australia Remembers Task Force in the Department of Veterans' Affairs is advised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 8 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australia Remembers: 1945-1995 Activity, why does the Application for Seeding Grant require applicants to state their Federal electorate?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senators' question:

PARA.TAB: The Australia Remembers 1945-1995 program provides funding of $20 000 for community activities in each federal electorate.

The application form for seeding funds requires applicants to state their federal electorate so that the Australia Remembers Task Force in the Department of Veterans' Affairs can ensure funds are not allocated beyond this limit.
My answer to Senate Question on Notice 1838 provides more detail on the application process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the planned relocation by March 1995 of the Civil Aviation Authority's Air Traffic Training Facility from the Launceston campus of the University of Tasmania to a mainland air traffic control centre:
(1) To where is the Launceston facility being relocated.
(2) Is the scheduled date for relocation on target; if not, why not.
(3) What is the estimated cost to the Australian taxpayer of relocating the facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Civil Aviation Authority's (CAA's) new Air Traffic Training Facility will have two campuses. These will be adjacent to Melbourne Airport (Tullamarine) and Brisbane Airport (Eagle Farm). The training facilities will operate in conjunction with the two major Air Traffic Service Centres under The Australian Advanced Air Traffic System (TAAATS).
(2) The timing for the relocation of the facility is on target. The scheduled date for the commencement of the first training course is 27 March 1995.

(3) There are no costs to the Australian taxpayer in relocating the facility. All costs incurred will be met from revenues recovered by the CAA through its normal charges to the aviation industry. However, the CAA estimates ongoing savings to the aviation industry of approximately $1.8 to $2.3 million per annum through a reduction in the cost of running training programs in the new facilities.
